questions.text: A patient presented with meningitis with a history of fever for 4 days and erythematous rashes on the chest. There was no history of travel and tick bite. His CSF findings showed increased protein, normal glucose, mild lymphocytosis and few RBCs. Which of the following is the most likely organism to cause this clinical picture? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Enterovirus

 

The clinical presentation and CSF findings are suggestive of viral meningitis, most probably caused by an Enterovirus. Enteroviruses are common causes of viral meningitis and present with fever, rashes, and mild lymphocytosis in the CSF.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. West Nile virus: Although it can cause meningitis, there is no history of travel, making this less likely. West Nile virus is endemic in certain regions of North America like California Central Valley, southwestern Arizona, southern Texas, and Louisiana, which have both compatible climates and avian reservoirs for the disease.

 

Option B. Meningococci: Typically causes bacterial meningitis with higher neutrophil count and lower glucose levels in the CSF.

 

Option C. Strep pneumoniae: Also typically causes bacterial meningitis with higher neutrophil count and lower glucose levels in the CSF.

 

Educational objective

 

CSF Findings for Different Types of Meningitis:

questions.text: A patient from a military background presented with rash, fever, and altered sensorium. There is also a deficiency of the membrane attacking complex. The likely cause can be: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neisseria meningitidis

 

Neisseria meningitidis is a bacterium that commonly causes meningococcal infections, which can lead to serious conditions such as meningococcemia and meningitis. Patients with a deficiency in the membrane attack complex (MAC) of the complement system, specifically components C5 to C9, are at an increased risk of Neisserial infections. The MAC plays a crucial role in defending against Neisseria species by forming pores in the bacterial cell membrane, leading to cell lysis. Without this complex, individuals are susceptible to recurrent or disseminated Neisserial infections, which manifest with symptoms like rash, fever, and altered sensorium, as seen in this patient. The clinical presentation of rash, fever, and altered sensorium strongly suggests meningococcemia, a severe form of infection caused by Neisseria meningitidis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): CMV is a type of herpesvirus that can cause a variety of symptoms, primarily in immunocompromised individuals, but it does not typically present with rash, fever, and altered sensorium linked to MAC deficiency.

 

Option B. Klebsiella pneumoniae: This bacterium is associated with pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and other infections, particularly in hospital settings. It does not have a direct correlation with MAC deficiency and does not typically present with disseminated infections characterized by rash, fever, and altered sensorium.

 

Option D. Hemophilus influenzae: While Hemophilus influenzae can cause respiratory tract infections and meningitis, it is not specifically associated with MAC deficiency and does not fit the profile of disseminated Neisserial infections seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with deficiencies in the membrane attack complex (C5-C9) of the complement system are particularly susceptible to infections caused by Neisseria species, such as Neisseria meningitidis, which can lead to severe conditions like meningococcemia.

questions.text: A patient admitted with 50% burns develops an infection at the burn site. The swab was cultured, the isolate is a strict aerobe and the test that is shown in the image is positive. What is the likely etiology of the burn infection? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pseudomonas aeruginosa

 

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most common cause of infection in the case of a burn. The given image shows a positive oxidase test. Psuedomonas aeruginosa is a strict aerobe and shows a positive oxidase reaction.

 

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative, catalase-positive, oxidase-positive, non-lactose fermenting bacteria that shows swarming motility. They produce a characteristic blue-green pigment called pyocyanin and a greenish-yellow pigment called fluorescein/pyoverdin. Other pigments produced by these organisms include pyorubin (Red), pyomelanin (Brown).

 

Diseases caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa include-

 

  • ﻿﻿Malignant otitis externa in diabetics
  • ﻿﻿Pneumonia and sepsis in cystic fibrosis
  • ﻿﻿Wound infection and sepsis in burns
  • ﻿﻿Hot tub folliculitis/Pseudomonas aeruginosa folliculitis/ Jacuzzi syndrome is a type of folliculitis, occurring after hot tub exposure
  • ﻿﻿Shanghai fever is a febrile illness that manifests as severe enteric disease, sepsis with invasive disease.
  • ﻿﻿Ecthyma gangrenosum

 

Pathogenesis - It is an obligate aerobe that exerts its pathogenicity by the production of diphtheria-like exotoxin A and a slime layer

 

Pseudomonas aeruginosa growth in a nutrient agar showing green coloured colonies are shown in the image below.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Klebsiella: While also a common hospital-acquired pathogen, it is typically associated with respiratory and urinary tract infections, not specifically burns.

 

Option B. Escherichia coli: Commonly causes gastrointestinal and urinary infections but is not typically associated with burn infections.

 

Option D. Salmonella: Known for causing gastrointestinal infections, not burn wound infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The identification of Pseudomonas aeruginosa in a burn wound infection is crucial due to its potential for rapid spread and resistance to treatment. Early detection and aggressive management are key to preventing severe complications such as sepsis or further tissue damage.

 

Oxidase test can be used to distinguish organisms by detecting the presence or absence of a respiratory enzyme, cytochrome oxidase. Cytochrome oxidase catalyzes the oxidation of reduced cytochrome by oxygen. Enterobacteriacee (Klebsiella, E. coli, Salmonella) are oxidase negative.

 

Oxidase positive organisms:

 

  • ﻿﻿Pseudomonas
  • ﻿﻿Vibrio
  • ﻿﻿Helicobacter
  • ﻿﻿Campylobacter
  • ﻿﻿Pasteurella
  • ﻿﻿Legionella
  • ﻿﻿Neisseria
  • ﻿﻿Brucella
  • ﻿﻿Moraxella
  • ﻿Burkholderia

questions.text: Which of the following test is used for antibiotic sensitivity? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) E-test (Epsilometer test)

 

The E-test or Epsilometer test is specifically designed for antibiotic sensitivity testing. It involves:

 

  • Using a Muller-Hinton agar (MHA) plate as the culture medium
  • Streaking the test organism on the plate
  • Applying an E-strip containing gradients of antibiotic concentrations
  • The strip has increasing antibiotic concentration going up and decreasing concentration going down
  • Where the zone of inhibition intersects the strip indicates the Minimum Inhibitory Concentration (MIC) of the antibiotic
  • Formation of an elliptical zone of inhibition around the strip indicates susceptibility

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elek's test

 

  • This is used for detecting diphtheria toxin production by Corynebacterium diphtheriae
  • It's a gel precipitation test where antitoxin strips are used to detect toxin production
  • Not related to antibiotic sensitivity testing

 

Option C. Latex agglutination test

 

  • This is an agglutination-based test used for various diagnostic purposes
  • Used for detecting antigens or antibodies in clinical specimens
  • Not used for determining antibiotic sensitivity

 

Option D. CAMP test

 

  • Used to detect beta-hemolysis
  • Primarily used for identifying Group B Streptococcus (S. agalactiae) and Listeria
  • Not related to antibiotic susceptibility testing

 

Educational Objective:

 

The E-test (Epsilometer test) is the standard method for determining the Minimum Inhibitory Concentration (MIC) of antibiotics against bacteria using an antibiotic gradient strip.

questions.text: Microfilariae with sheathed tail and two nuclei at the tail tip is suggestive of: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Brugia malayi

 

The most likely organism based on the description of the microfilariae is Brugia malayi.

 

The microfilariae of B. malayi are sheathed and have kinks and secondary curves. The tail tip has two nuclei - a terminal and a subterminal one. It has nocturnal periodicity.

 

The female filarial worms, which belong to the phylum Nematoda, give birth to larvae known as microfilariae.

 

Some of the microfilariae retain their egg membranes and are known as sheathed microfilariae. They can be further differentiated on the basis of the arrangement of nuclei in the tail.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wuchereria bancrofti: Also causes lymphatic filariasis but does not have two distinct nuclei at the tail tip of its microfilariae.

 

Option C. Loa loa: Known for daytime periodicity and does not show the characteristic two nuclei at the tail tip.

 

Option D. Onchocerca volvulus: Does not circulate in peripheral blood; instead, its microfilariae are found in skin and connective tissues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The identification of microfilariae with a sheathed tail and two nuclei at the tail tip is a diagnostic feature of Brugia malayi, crucial for distinguishing it from other filarial infections. This morphological detail is important for correct diagnosis and appropriate management of lymphatic filariasis.

choices.text: Rabbit ileal loop for enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli
Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a suspected dengue patient
Injecting a hamster with splenic biopsy for diagnosis of leishmaniasis
Intradermal test on guinea pigs for toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheria

questions.text: Which of the following is a Xenodiagnostic method? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a suspected dengue patient

 

Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a suspected dengue patient is the Xeno diagnostic method among the given options.

 

Xenodiagnosis is a diagnostic method used to document the presence of infectious disease microorganisms or pathogens by exposing possibly infected tissue to a vector and then examining the vector for the presence of the microorganisms or pathogens it may have ingested.

 

Uses -

 

  1. Chagas disease diagnosis. Reduviid bugs (vector/foreign host) grown in laboratories are permitted to feed on suspicious patients (original host). The feces of the bugs are checked under a microscope for amastigote forms of the pathogen Trypanosoma cruzi after 4-5 weeks.
  2. Identification of dengue virus – viruses are inoculated into the mosquitoes . The virus can be demonstrated easily as it multiplies in different organs of the mosquito (Aedes aegypti, Aedes albopictus, and Toxorhynchites) and can be easily demonstrated.
  3. In Trichinella spirals infection, Laboratory rats are used as a T. spiralis vector by feeding them pieces of muscle biopsies from suspected patients. The infected lab rats' muscles can be seen to contain T. spiralis larvae.

 

Advantage of xenodiagnosis: helpful in cases where low pathogen count makes direct microscopic diagnosis DIFFICULT.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Rabbit ileal loop for enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli: Incorrect: This is not a xenodiagnostic method. It involves testing the virulence of enterotoxigenic E. coli by observing the fluid accumulation in ligated sections of rabbit intestine.

 

Option C. Injecting a hamster with splenic biopsy for diagnosis of leishmaniasis: Incorrect: This method involves animal inoculation rather than using a vector to diagnose an infection.

 

Option D. Intradermal test on guinea pigs for toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheria: Incorrect: This is a virulence testing method to determine the presence of toxigenic strains of Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

 

Educational Objective

 

Xenodiagnosis involves using a vector to ingest potentially infected tissue or fluids and then examining the vector for the presence of the pathogen, making it particularly useful in cases where direct detection of the pathogen is challenging due to low numbers.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with a history of vomiting within 3 hours of consumption of food at a party. Which of the following organism is most likely to cause these symptoms? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Staphylococcus aureus

 

The most likely causative organism in the given scenario is Staphylococcus aureus. It causes food poisoning within 30 minutes to 6 hours after consumption of the contaminated food.

 

The common sources of infection are the foods that are not cooked after handling. These include sliced meats, puddings, pastries, and sandwiches. Patients present with nausea, vomiting, stomach cramps, and diarrhoea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Clostridium botulinum: Causes botulism, typically presenting with symptoms such as muscle weakness, paralysis, and respiratory failure rather than rapid-onset vomiting.

 

Option C. Clostridium perfringens: Associated with gastroenteritis that causes abdominal cramps and diarrhea, typically occurring 8-16 hours after consumption of contaminated food.

 

Option D. Salmonella typhi: Causes typhoid fever, characterized by prolonged fever, abdominal pain, and other systemic symptoms, rather than immediate vomiting.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: Which of the following organisms causes scombroid fish poisoning? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pseudomonas aeruginosa

 

Scombroid fish poisoning is associated with Pseudomonas aeruginosa. It follows the consumption of both scombroid (mackerel-like) fish and nonscombroid fish that has not been refrigerated properly. The musculature of these dark- or red-fleshed fish undergoes decomposition by Morganella morganii, Escherichia coli, Proteus species, Klebsiella species, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa with consequent decarboxylation of the amino acid L-histidine to form histamine.

 

Symptoms develop within 15-90 min of ingestion. Most cases are mild, with tingling of lips and mouth, mild abdominal discomfort, and nausea. The more severe and commonly described presentation includes flushing, conjunctival hyperemia, pruritus, urticaria, and angioedema. Without treatment, the symptoms generally resolve within 8-12 h.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Salmonella: Incorrect because Salmonella is not typically involved in the histamine production leading to scombroid fish poisoning.

 

Option B. Staphylococcus: Incorrect as Staphylococcus does not contribute to histamine production in fish, which is the primary cause of scombroid poisoning.

 

Option D. Peptostreptococcus: Incorrect because Peptostreptococcus is not associated with the decomposition of fish that leads to histamine production and subsequent scombroid fish poisoning.

 

Educational Objective

 

Scombroid fish poisoning is primarily caused by the decarboxylation of L-histidine into histamine by bacteria such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa in improperly stored fish, leading to a range of symptoms from mild gastrointestinal discomfort to severe allergic reactions.

questions.text: Identify the organism by this Test? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Haemophilus influenzae

 

The test shown is satellitism, a characteristic growth pattern of Haemophilus influenzae on blood agar. 

 

H. influenzae requires two growth factors: Factor X (hemin/hematin) and Factor V (NAD - Nicotinamide Adenine Dinucleotide). While Factor X is freely available in blood agar, Factor V is largely intracellular within RBCs and only available in minute quantities. 

 

When Staphylococcus aureus is streaked across the blood agar plate, it releases Factor V (NAD) into the surrounding medium. This results in H. influenzae forming larger colonies adjacent to the S. aureus streak line, with colony size gradually decreasing as distance from the streak increases, creating a "satellite" appearance. This phenomenon helps identify H. influenzae and demonstrates its fastidious growth requirements.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Group B streptococcus: Shows CAMP test positivity (arrow-head hemolysis) when streaked perpendicular to S. aureus, not satellitism. It doesn't require X and V factors for growth.

 

Option C. Corynebacterium diphtheriae: Grows on specialized media like Loeffler's serum slope or tellurite media. Does not show satellitism and doesn't require X and V factors.

 

Option D. Clostridium tetani: An anaerobic, spore-forming bacterium that shows drumstick appearance due to terminal spores. Does not demonstrate satellitism and grows under anaerobic conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Satellitism is the characteristic growth pattern of Haemophilus influenzae around Staphylococcus aureus on blood agar, demonstrating its requirement for both Factor X (hemin) and Factor V (NAD).

questions.text: Following images show the sample collected from a patient complaining of perianal itching. The diagnosis is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Enterobius vermicularis

 

Enterobius vermicularis, commonly known as pinworm, is the most common cause of perianal itching, especially in children. This worm lays its eggs around the perianal region, which leads to intense itching. The characteristic D-shaped (plano-convex) eggs seen in the images further confirm the diagnosis of Enterobius vermicularis. The images depict the typical appearance of the worm’s head and its eggs, which have a clear, thick shell with one flattened side.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ancylostoma: Ancylostoma, also known as hookworm, typically causes symptoms like iron deficiency anemia due to blood loss from the intestines. It does not typically cause perianal itching, and its eggs are not D-shaped.

 

Option C. H Nana: Hymenolepis nana, the dwarf tapeworm, causes hymenolepiasis, which can present with gastrointestinal symptoms but not specifically perianal itching. Its eggs are spherical with polar filaments, which are distinctly different from the D-shaped eggs of Enterobius vermicularis.

 

Option D. Necator americanus: This is another type of hookworm that primarily causes symptoms related to iron deficiency anemia and gastrointestinal discomfort. It does not typically cause perianal itching, and its eggs are oval with a thin, smooth shell, different from those of Enterobius vermicularis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enterobius vermicularis is associated with perianal itching and produces characteristic D-shaped eggs.

questions.text: A patient present with multiple episodes or bloody diarrhea. On investigation of blood sample Enterohemorrhagic strain of E. Coli was isolated. On which of the following media this organism can be cultured? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sorbitol MacConkey agar

 

EHEC

 

  • ﻿﻿O157: H7
  • ﻿﻿O: somatic antigen
  • ﻿﻿H: Flagellar antigen
  • ﻿﻿Causes Haemolytic uremic Syndrome & haemorrhagic colitis in children

 

EHEC is primarily transmitted through the consumption of contaminated food, particularly undercooked ground beef, raw vegetables, and unpasteurized dairy products. Person-to-person transmission can also occur through contact with fecal matter.

 

In severe cases, EHEC infection can lead to a complication known as hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS), which can cause kidney failure and other serious health problems. HUS is more likely to occur in children, older adults, and individuals with weakened immune systems.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TCBS (Thiosulfate-citrate-bile salts-sucrose agar): This medium is selective for Vibrio species and is not suitable for the isolation of E. coli, including EHEC.

 

Option B. Selenite F broth: This is an enrichment medium used primarily for the isolation of Salmonella species. It is not specific for E. coli.

 

Option C. Robertson cooked meat media: This is an enrichment medium used for the cultivation of anaerobes. It is not suitable for the isolation of E. coli.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sorbitol MacConkey agar is the preferred medium for the isolation and differentiation of Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) strains such as O157, which do not ferment sorbitol, resulting in colorless colonies on this medium.

choices.text: Cannot be differentiated serologically from T. pallidum

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Yaws is not true? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Spread by sexual transmission

 

Explanation:

 

Yaws is not spread by sexual transmission. It is a non-venereal treponematosis caused by Treponema pertenue that spreads through direct contact with infected skin lesions. The disease primarily affects children in tropical regions, with transmission occurring through skin-to-skin contact during play or other close physical contact. Unlike syphilis, which is sexually transmitted, yaws spreads through non-sexual contact primarily in rural communities with poor hygiene.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Caused by T. pertenue - This statement is true. Yaws is indeed caused by Treponema pertenue, which is a non-venereal Treponema species closely related to T. pallidum (the causative agent of syphilis). The spirochete morphologically resembles T. pallidum but has different transmission patterns and epidemiology.

 

Option C. Has cross immunity with syphilis - This statement is true. Yaws provides cross immunity with syphilis because both organisms share common antigens. This cross-immunity has epidemiological significance, as regions with high prevalence of yaws typically have lower rates of syphilis.

 

Option D. Cannot be differentiated serologically from T. pallidum - This statement is true. Standard serological tests cannot differentiate between antibodies produced in response to T. pallidum and those produced in response to T. pertenue infection. Both infections produce positive results in non-treponemal tests (VDRL, RPR) and treponemal tests (FTA-ABS, TPHA).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Yaws is a non-venereal treponematosis caused by T. pertenue that spreads through direct skin contact, primarily affecting children in tropical regions, and while it shares many features with syphilis including cross-immunity and serological similarities, it differs fundamentally in its mode of transmission.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about cutaneous anthrax, except: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Wool Sorter's disease

 

Explanation:

 

Wool Sorter's disease is NOT a feature of cutaneous anthrax but rather refers to pulmonary anthrax. Wool Sorter's disease is specifically the inhalational form of anthrax that occurs when spores are inhaled, typically among workers handling contaminated wool, hides, or other animal products. It affects the respiratory system, presenting with flu-like symptoms that progress to severe respiratory distress, and has historically had a very high mortality rate (approaching 100% if untreated).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malignant pustule - This statement is true about cutaneous anthrax. The characteristic lesion of cutaneous anthrax is known as a "malignant pustule." This term describes the central necrotic, painless lesion that develops at the site of inoculation after spores enter through breaks in the skin.

 

Option B. Hide Porter's disease - This statement is true about cutaneous anthrax. "Hide Porter's disease" is another name for cutaneous anthrax, named after the occupational risk faced by workers who carried (ported) animal hides, which could be contaminated with anthrax spores.

 

Option C. Black eschar - This statement is true about cutaneous anthrax. The development of a black eschar is the hallmark of cutaneous anthrax. The lesion begins as a painless papule that vesiculates and eventually develops into a characteristic black, necrotic eschar surrounded by non-pitting edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The three forms of anthrax have distinct clinical presentations and names: cutaneous anthrax (Hide Porter's disease, malignant pustule) presents with a characteristic painless black eschar; pulmonary anthrax (Wool Sorter's disease) presents with respiratory symptoms; and gastrointestinal anthrax affects the digestive tract after consuming contaminated meat.

choices.text: Clindamycin 600 mg intravenously 8 hourly for 7 days
Artesunate 2.4 mg/kg intravenously at 12 and 24 hours, followed by daily once

questions.text: A patient comes with a history of high fever for 5 days and altered sensorium. On further probing, it was found that he had two seizures one day ago. Peripheral smear shows the following findings. How will you manage this patient? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Artesunate 2.4 mg/kg intravenously at 12 and 24 hours, followed by daily once

 

A Giemsa-stained peripheral blood smear shows many red blood cells (RBCs) infected with classic, ring-shaped and headphone-shaped trophozoites of Plasmodium falciparum parasite. High degree of parasitemia and RBCs infected with two or more trophozoites were seen, a finding typical of P. falciparum malaria.

 

Cerebral malaria is a complicated form of malaria associated with multisystem organ dysfunction and high degree of morbidity and mortality. These patients often present with impaired consciousness, delirium and convulsions. It is a medical emergency where prompt diagnosis and early institution of treatment can be lifesaving. Intravenous quinine or artesunate are the mainstays of treatment in cerebral malaria.

 

Management of Cerebral Malaria:

 

  • Artesunate: Administered intravenously at a dose of 2.4 mg/kg immediately, followed by 2.4 mg/kg at 12 and 24 hours, and then once daily if necessary.
  • Alternative Treatment:
    • Artemether: 3.2 mg/kg intramuscularly initially, followed by 1.6 mg/kg once daily.
    • Quinine dihydrochloride: 20 mg of salt/kg infused over 4 hours, followed by 10 mg of salt/kg infused over 2-8 hours.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Doxycycline 100 mg intravenously for 7 days: Doxycycline is not the first-line treatment for severe malaria. It is typically used as a secondary prophylactic measure or in combination with other antimalarial drugs.

 

Option B. Clindamycin 600 mg intravenously 8 hourly for 7 days: Clindamycin is not used for the treatment of malaria. It is an antibiotic that is used for bacterial infections.

 

Option D. Chloroquine intramuscularly 8 hourly for 3 days: Chloroquine is ineffective against Plasmodium falciparum due to widespread resistance. It is also not suitable for treating severe or cerebral malaria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cerebral malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum is a medical emergency requiring prompt treatment with intravenous artesunate, which is the most effective and rapid-acting medication for severe malaria.

choices.text: Cyst contents can produce anaphylactic reaction
A segmented dog tapeworm is the causative agent
FNAC or biopsy to be done before nephrectomy

questions.text: A patient presents to you with left-sided flank pain. A CT scan was done which is shown below. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the condition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) FNAC or biopsy to be done before nephrectomy

 

Above CT image shows left renal hydatid cyst. In this case, FNAC or biopsy should not be done before nephrectomy as puncture of the cyst while obtaining cystic fluid may cause escape of hydatid fluid and consequent anaphylaxis. Therefore, fluid aspirated from surgically removed cyst should only be examined.

 

Echinococcus causes hydatid cyst in man. It is segmented and smaller than other cestodes.

 

Most of the times infection is asymptomatic and accidentally discovered.

 

Clinical disease develops only when the hydatid cyst has grown big enough to cause obstructive symptoms. Disease results mainly from pressure effects caused by the enlarging cysts.

 

In about half the cases, the primary hydatid cyst occurs in liver, mostly in the right lobe. Hepatomegaly, pain and obstructive jaundice are the usual manifestations.

 

The next common site is the lung (25%) (most common being the lower lobe of the right lung). Cough, hemoptysis, chest pain, pneumothorax and dyspnea constitute the clinical picture.

 

In the kidney (2%), hydatid cyst causes pain and hematuria.

 

Apart from pressure effects, another pathogenic mechanism in hydatid disease is hypersensitivity to the echinococcal antigen. The host is sensitized to the antigen by minute amounts of hydatid fluid seeping through the capsule. Hypersensitivity may cause urticaria. But if a hydatid cyst ruptures spontaneously or during surgical interference/FNAC, massive release of hydatid fluid may cause severe, even fatal anaphylaxis.

 

CT imaging is diagnostic to visualize daughter cysts within large cysts

 

Treatment

 

Traditionally surgical removal was considered as the best mode of treatment of cysts.

 

Currently, ultrasound staging is recommended and management depends on the stage.

 

In early stages, the treatment of choice is puncture, aspiration, injection and reaspiration (PAIR).

 

Puncture, aspiration, injection and reaspiration, considered as a controversial procedure earlier, is now widely used in early stages of the disease. The basic steps involved in PAlR include:

 

  • Ultrasound or CT-guided puncture of the cyst.
  • Aspiration of cyst fluid.
  • Infusion of sporicidal agent (usually 95% ethanol; alternatively, hypertonic saline)
  • Reaspiration of the fluid after 5 minutes.
  • Great care is taken to avoid spillage and cavities are sterilized with 0.5% silver nitrate or 2.7% sodium chloride for prophylaxis of secondary peritoneal echinococcosis due to inadvertent spillage of fluid du ring PAIR.

 

Albendazole (15 mg/ kg in row divided doses) is initiated 4 days before the procedure and continued for 4 weeks afterwards.

 

Surgery: It is the treatment of choice for complicated E. granulosus cysts like those communicating with the biliary tract and in those cysts where PAIR is not possible.

 

Renal involvement requires surgical treatment, either simple excision of the cyst or partial/total nephrectomy if extensive disease.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Albendazole can be started preoperatively: This is correct. Albendazole (15 mg/kg in two divided doses) is initiated 4 days before any surgical or puncture procedure and continued for 4 weeks afterwards to reduce the risk of spillage and subsequent anaphylactic reaction.

 

Option B. Cyst contents can produce anaphylactic reaction: This is correct. The contents of a hydatid cyst contain highly antigenic material, and rupture or spillage of this material can cause a severe anaphylactic reaction.

 

Option C. A segmented dog tapeworm is the causative agent: This is correct. Echinococcus granulosus, a segmented tapeworm found in dogs, is the causative agent of hydatid disease.

 

Educational Objective

 

Hydatid disease, caused by Echinococcus granulosus, is characterized by cyst formation in organs such as the liver, lungs, and kidneys. FNAC or biopsy should not be done in cases of suspected hydatid cysts due to the risk of anaphylaxis and dissemination of the infection.

questions.text: A patient came with infective endocarditis. Examination showed gram-positive cocci in chains. What is the likely etiological agent? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Streptococcus viridans

 

The key points that indicate Streptococcus viridans as the causative agent are:

 

1. The patient has infective endocarditis, which is commonly caused by Streptococcus viridans.

 

 

2. The microscopic examination showed gram-positive cocci arranged in chains, which is a characteristic morphology of Streptococcus viridans.

 

3. The image provided also confirms the presence of gram-positive cocci (violet color) arranged in long chains.

 

4. Among the options, Streptococcus pneumoniae and Enterococcus typically appear as diplococci (in pairs) and not in chains, ruling them out.

 

5. Streptococcus pyogenes is more commonly associated with rheumatic fever endocarditis rather than infective endocarditis.

 

Gram Positive cocci

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Streptococcus pyogenes: This beta-hemolytic streptococcus is a common cause of rheumatic fever and pharyngitis but not typically associated with infective endocarditis.

 

 

Option C. Streptococcus pneumoniae: This alpha-hemolytic streptococcus appears as gram-positive diplococci (in pairs) and is a common cause of pneumonia but not a typical cause of infective endocarditis.

 

Option D. Enterococcus: These gram-positive cocci also appear in pairs (diplococci) and are not commonly associated with infective endocarditis.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Streptococcus viridans, an alpha-hemolytic streptococcus found in the normal oral flora, is a common cause of infective endocarditis, particularly in patients with underlying heart valve abnormalities or prosthetic heart valves. Its characteristic microscopic appearance of gram-positive cocci arranged in chains is a key diagnostic feature.

questions.text: Which of the following is classified under Biosafety level -3 infections? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) XDR-TB

 

Explanation:

 

XDR-TB (Extensively Drug-Resistant Tuberculosis) requires BSL-3 (Biosafety Level 3) containment due to its high risk of airborne transmission and severe disease potential.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Salmonella: Generally handled under BSL-2 due to lower risk.

 

Option C. Ebola: Handled under BSL-4, given its high risk and lethality.

 

Option D. Congo Crimean Fever: Also requires BSL-4 due to high fatality rates and transmission risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classification of pathogens is according to biosafety levels. XDR-TB is managed under BSL-3 conditions due to its airborne risks and drug resistance challenges.

choices.text: Assertion is true, reason is true; reason is the correct explanation for the assertion
Assertion is true, reason is true; reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion
Assertion is false and reason is also true
Assertion is true and reason is also false

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Myocarditis is the common known complication of faucial diphtheria


Reason (R) : It is due to bacteremia by diphtheria    (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Assertion is true and reason is also false

 

Explanation:

 

Assertion: Myocarditis is indeed a common and serious complication of diphtheria, especially in cases of faucial diphtheria. The diphtheria toxin can cause significant damage to the heart muscle, leading to myocarditis.

 

Reason: The assertion that myocarditis is due to bacteremia by diphtheria is incorrect. Diphtheria does not cause bacteremia. Instead, the complications, including myocarditis, are due to the exotoxin produced by the Corynebacterium diphtheriae. The toxin disseminates through the bloodstream, affecting various organs, including the heart, nerves, and kidneys.

 

  1. Diphtheria Toxin: The pathogenesis of diphtheria involves the production of diphtheria toxin, which is a potent exotoxin. This toxin, rather than the bacteria itself, enters the bloodstream (toxemia) and affects distant organs.
  2. Toxemia vs. Bacteremia: Diphtheria is characterized by toxemia, not bacteremia. The bacteria remain localized at the site of infection (e.g., the throat), but the toxin spreads systemically.
  3. Myocarditis as a Complication: The diphtheria toxin affects the heart muscle, leading to myocarditis, which is the most common and severe complication of diphtheria. Other complications include neuritis and damage to the adrenal glands.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Assertion is true, reason is true; reason is the correct explanation for the assertion: Incorrect because the reason given is not the correct explanation.

 

Option B. Assertion is true, reason is true; reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion: Incorrect because the reason itself is false.

 

Option C. Assertion is false and reason is also true: Incorrect because the assertion is true, but the reason is false.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myocarditis is a common and serious complication of diphtheria due to the effects of the diphtheria toxin. It is important to recognize that the complications arise from toxemia, not bacteremia.

questions.text: Identify the organism in the given image. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mucor

 

Histopathological staining shows broad septate, hyaline hyphae with wide angle branching, which suggests that it is more likely Mucor.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Aspergillus: Aspergillus shows aseptate narrow hyphae with acute angle branching.

 

Option C. Talaromyces: Talaromyces is a genus of fungi that forms septate hyphae and conidiophores.

 

Option D. Blastomyces: Blastomyces dermatitidis is a dimorphic fungus that appears as broad-based budding yeast in tissue sections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucor is identified by broad aseptate hyaline hyphae with wide-angle branching, and it typically lacks rhizoids, unlike Rhizopus which has nodal rhizoids.

questions.text: A 78-year-old patient was urgently brought to the casualty department due to recurring episodes of severe breathlessness. The patient mentioned experiencing a fever and cough over the last three days. To investigate the underlying cause of the symptoms, laboratory tests were conducted, and the test report indicated the presence of target sequences for the RdRp gene, E gene, N gene, and ORF1ab. Which diagnostic test was most likely performed to obtain these results? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) RT-PCR

 

The given clinical scenario, along with target sequences for RdRp, E gene, N gene and ORF1ab is suggestive of COVID-19. The gold standard for its diagnosis is the identification of viral genome targets in the respiratory tract materials by reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CLIA (Chemiluminescent Immunoassay): Used for detecting antibodies or antigens in blood samples but not for detecting viral RNA directly.

 

Option B. ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay): Typically used for detecting antibodies or antigens in blood samples, not for direct viral RNA detection.

 

Option C. CBNAAT (Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test): Used for detecting specific nucleic acids in pathogens like Mycobacterium tuberculosis but not commonly used for COVID-19 diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RT-PCR is the gold standard diagnostic test for detecting COVID-19 by identifying specific genetic sequences of the SARS-CoV-2 virus in respiratory samples.

questions.text: The following tzanck smear finding is seen in? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HSV

 

Given tzanck smear finding is seen in HSV

 

The Tzanck smear shows multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogeneously stained ground-glass chromatin, which are characteristic of HSV infection. This test is commonly used to diagnose herpes infections, including HSV-1 and HSV-2, and can also detect varicella-zoster virus (the cause of chickenpox and shingles).

 

It used to diagnose some skin blistering disorders for ex: Darier's disease, Hailey-Hailey disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chicken pox: Incorrect. While Tzanck smears can be used to diagnose varicella-zoster virus infections, the specific question and provided image are more indicative of HSV.

 

Option C. HIV: Incorrect. HIV is not typically diagnosed with a Tzanck smear. HIV diagnosis is usually confirmed with blood tests, including ELISA and Western blot.

 

Option D. HPV: Incorrect. Human papillomavirus (HPV) is not diagnosed with a Tzanck smear. HPV diagnosis usually involves DNA tests and Pap smears for cervical lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tzanck smears are useful for diagnosing skin infections caused by herpes viruses, including HSV-1 and HSV-2. The presence of multinucleated giant cells with ground-glass chromatin is a hallmark of HSV infection.

questions.text: The endotoxin of which gram-negative bacterium does not play a role in the pathogenesis of the disease it causes? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Vibrio cholerae

 

Explanation:

 

Vibrio cholerae is the correct answer because unlike typical Gram-negative infections, the pathogenesis of cholera is primarily mediated by an exotoxin (cholera toxin) rather than its endotoxin. Cholera toxin activates adenylate cyclase in intestinal epithelial cells, leading to massive secretion of water and electrolytes, resulting in the characteristic profuse, watery "rice-water" diarrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. E. coli - The endotoxin (lipopolysaccharide) of E. coli plays a significant role in its pathogenesis, particularly in septic shock. The endotoxin activates inflammatory pathways, complement cascades, and can lead to fever, hypotension, and disseminated intravascular coagulation.

 

Option B. Klebsiella - The endotoxin of Klebsiella is a major virulence factor in its pathogenesis. During infection, Klebsiella's endotoxin contributes to the inflammatory response, potential septic shock, and tissue damage.

 

Option D. Pseudomonas aeruginosa - Endotoxin plays an important role in Pseudomonas infections. The lipopolysaccharide component of P. aeruginosa activates inflammatory responses contributing to tissue damage and systemic effects during infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While all Gram-negative bacteria contain endotoxin (lipopolysaccharide) in their cell walls, the relative importance of this component in disease pathogenesis varies. For Vibrio cholerae, the exotoxin (cholera toxin) is the primary virulence factor responsible for the characteristic clinical manifestations.

questions.text: A patient presents with gastrointestinal problems including abdominal pain and distension, bloody and mucus-filled diarrhea, and tenesmus, with rectal prolapse. A stool examination reveals the presence of typical barrel-shaped eggs. What is the possible causative agent? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trichuris trichiura

 

The given clinical picture and the barrel-shaped eggs are suggestive of infection with Trichuris trichiura (whipworm).

 

The characteristic features of whipworm eggs are:

 

  • Eggs are barrel-shaped in the middle with a projecting mucus plug at each pole containing an unsegmented ovum. The plugs are colorless.
  • They float in the saturated salt solution.
  • It has a triple shell, the outermost layer of which is stained brown.

 

Other Options


Option A. Giardia lamblia: The stool examination usually reveals oval-shaped cysts or trophozoites. Giardia does not produce eggs, distinguishing it from helminthic infections.

 

Option C. Ascaris lumbricoides: The eggs are typically oval-shaped and brown-colored. They have a distinct thick shell and are not barrel-shaped, which helps differentiate them from Trichuris trichiura eggs.

 

 

Option D. Ancylostoma duodenale:  The eggs are oval and thin-shelled, significantly different in appearance from the barrel-shaped eggs of Trichuris trichiura.

 

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Table listing appearance of various organism in stool/sputum examination

questions.text: A lady from West Rajasthan presented with an ulcer surrounded by erythema on the right leg. Microscopy of the biopsy from the edge of the ulcer showed organisms with dark staining nuclei and kinetoplast. What is the most likely causative agent? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leishmania tropica

 

The above clinical vignette is suggestive of cutaneous leishmaniasis, caused by Leishmania tropica

 

 

Difference between Leishmania tropica and donovani is that tropica do not invade organs. It causes cutaneous leishmaniasis otherwise called as Delhi boil, Aleppo boil.

 

Following image shows an ulcer surrounded by erythema

 

 

In India, it is endemic to Bihar, West Bengal, Jharkhand, and Uttar Pradesh.

 

The image given below shows a phlebotomus sandfly.

 

 

LIFE CYCLE IS GIVEN OF FILARIA:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Babesia causes babesiosis, a tick-borne disease, presents as a malaria-like illness with fever, chills, and hemolytic anemia.

 

Option C. Trypanosoma cause diseases like African trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness) and American trypanosomiasis (Chagas disease), presents with different clinical features, such as fever, swollen lymph nodes, and neurological symptoms in African trypanosomiasis while in Chagas disease, fever and swelling at the infection site, and cardiomyopathy.

 

Option D. Histoplasma (dimorphic fungus) causes histoplasmosis. Mostly affects the lungs and then can disseminate to other organs in immunocompromised individuals. Presents variably, but it does not typically cause an ulcer with erythema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leishmania tropica is the causative agent of cutaneous leishmaniasis, leading to skin ulcers that can be identified by microscopy showing organisms with kinetoplasts. Awareness of this condition is crucial for correct diagnosis and management, particularly in endemic areas like parts of Rajasthan, India.

questions.text: Identify the organism shown in this image? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ascaris lumbricoides

 

The roundworm, Ascaris lumbricoides is the largest nematode parasite in the human intestine.

 

They are large cylindrical worms with tapered ends.

 

The anterior end is more pointed than the posterior.

 

They are pale pink or flesh coloured when freshly passed in stools, but become white outside the body.

 

The mouth at the anterior end has three finely toothed lips, one dorsal and two ventrolateral

 

Habitat - Small intestine (85% in the jejunum and 15% in the ileum).

 

Natural host – Man

 

Infective form – embryonated eggs containing infective rhabditiform larvae

 

Mode of transmission – feco-oral route

 

Disease caused by A. lumbricoides is called as ascariasis.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Strongyloides stercoralis: This nematode causes strongyloidiasis and is much smaller and thread-like in appearance compared to Ascaris lumbricoides.

 

Option B. Enterobius vermicularis: Commonly known as pinworm, this parasite is much smaller and thinner than Ascaris lumbricoides and is primarily found in the colon and rectum.

 

Option C. Ancylostoma duodenale: This is a hookworm that has a different morphology with a characteristic curved anterior end, and it primarily inhabits the small intestine where it attaches to the mucosa.

 

Educational Objective

 

Ascaris lumbricoides is the largest nematode parasite in the human intestine, identifiable by its large size, cylindrical shape with tapered ends, and characteristic mouth with three finely toothed lips.
